name: Badge (redo-tables)
htmlBanner:
Badge

Badges convey dynamic, temporary information, such as counts or status. A badge can include labels or numbers.

Accessibility.html:
Overview

The badge component is a visual indicator of status. Provide alternative text‚Ä®Because it typically does not contain text, it is very important to have the appropriate alternate text available. WCAG 1.1.1 Not focusable

Example

When a notification is witnessed on an icon, the screen reader should be able to indicate that to the user. In this example it should read:

Label [Messages] One new notification.

Or, when there is only a dot, it should read: ‚ÄúLabel [Messages] One notification.‚Äù

Anatomy

Annotated visual example of the component in its default state.

Default Token values

Layout

Guideline.html:
Anatomy

Annotated visual example of the component in its default state.

Use Cases

Badges can be used as modifiers for buttons, tabs, or list items. However, make sure that you‚Äôre using them to communicate temporary information. For permanent information, leverage tags.

It is typically used in menu items to designate a part of the application that contains new or unread information. It can also be used in list items and on iconography.
Badges are temporary and will be cleared by the user, typically after selection.

When to use

Badges can be used to communicate status, particularly newness or unread status.
Notifications: Use badges to draw attention to new or unread notifications, such as messages or alerts.
Statuses: Use badges to indicate the status of an item or task, such as "In progress" or "Complete".
Counters: Use badges to display the number of items in a particular category or section, such as items in a shopping cart or results in a search.

When Not to use

Badges, particularly the label badge can be confused with the chip. Try to remember that badges communicate status, chips can be used to communicate category or type.
Overuse: Don't use badges excessively, as this can overwhelm the user and make the interface look cluttered.
Unimportant information: Don't use badges to draw attention to information that is not particularly important or relevant to the user.

Types

If there are multiple types of this component, showcase them and demonstrate how they‚Äôre different.

Unread

Used to indicate new or unread activity.

Counter

Used to indicate a specific number of objects which are new or unread.

Icon

Used for things like at-mention badges as well as alert badges.

Label

Used to indicate a temporary status of an object.

Behavior

The badge is temporary by definition. Users should have a way to clear them. Typically, this is done by viewing the content that the badge is indicating.

Dos and Dont‚Äôs

Use Appropriate size

Do use badges to indicate a quantity of new or unread information.

MakeDo not use the badge to indicate truncated information. It is solely used to indicate the quantity of new or unread information.

Do keep character limit to 4 or less characters on the counter badge.

Do not use more than 4 characters total in the counter badge.

Use a chip instead for situations like this, since it is denoting the category of this user (it‚Äôs a bot).

Do not use Label Badges as Chips to label static, categorical information that is not a status or cannot be dismissed by the user.

Content

Casing

Badges across all platforms use sentence case capitalization.

Character limits

All badges must use 4 characters or less. This is t

Spacing

Label text for counter

If there is more than the counter can show, use a +. Always use a + after your counter numbers. The + indicator counts toward total character count.

Label text for label badge

Label text can't exceed the 4-character limit on badges. You may use acronyms if it works for your context. If a longer word is required, consider using another component or way to add context.

Takeaways

Use badges with navigation items to convey dynamic information associated with that destination.
Small badges use only shape to indicate a status change or new notification.
Large badges display numbers within a container to indicate a quantifiable status change.

Related Components

Avatars

Component that represents a user.

Buttons

Buttons are used to trigger an action or to navigate to a different part of the application.
